A Mistaken Religious Ruling

Does an Exposed Knee Break Wudu'?

The text addresses the mistaken belief that an exposed knee during or after wudu' (ablution) breaks it. Some people think that if their knee is accidentally exposed while performing wudu' or at any point after completing it, the wudu' becomes invalid, requiring them to start over.

The Correct Islamic Ruling

This idea is incorrect.

  • What breaks wudu'? The things that break wudu' are well-known and include passing wind, urinating, defecating, etc. Exposing one's satar (body parts that must be covered) is not among them.

  • The Satar: While the knees are part of the satar and must be covered, exposing them does not invalidate wudu'. The author emphasizes that one should be careful to keep their knees covered during ablution to maintain modesty, but if they are accidentally exposed, the wudu' remains valid.

In conclusion, the claim that an exposed knee breaks wudu' is a baseless misconception.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, February 2012, www.alkawsar.com

This Is Not a Hadith

The text addresses a story that is sometimes told about Abu Bakr as-Siddiq (RA) and the Angel Jibreel (AS).

The Story and Its Refutation

The story claims that when Abu Bakr (RA) was wearing a coarse cloth garment (due to poverty or asceticism), Jibreel (AS) appeared to him in human form and asked, "Where is Jibreel now?" After Abu Bakr (RA) searched for Jibreel (AS) everywhere but couldn't find him, he realized the man was Jibreel (AS) himself. The angel then supposedly said he had a message for him: Abu Bakr's (RA) act was so beloved to Allah that all the angels were now wearing coarse garments in imitation of him.

The author of the text states that this story is completely fabricated.

  • It is not found in any reliable books of Hadith, Sirah (biography of the Prophet), or history.

  • It is also not found with an authentic chain of narration in any trustworthy book on Tasawwuf (Sufism).

The author condemns those who invent such stories, as they not only lie about people but also about the Prophet and even Allah. He warns readers to be cautious of such fabrications.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, March 2012, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Religious Ruling

Is Sajda al-Sahw Required for a Recitation Correction?

The provided text discusses the common misconception that a prostration of forgetfulness (sajda al-sahw) is required after receiving a recitation correction in prayer.

What is a "Lukmah"?

When a praying individual (Imam) makes a mistake in the recitation of the Quran during prayer and can't continue, a follower (muqtadi) may audibly recite the correct verses to help the Imam. This act is known as giving a "lukmah" (correction). A correction may also be given if the Imam makes a mistake in the movements of the prayer.

The Mistaken Belief

The author recounts an incident where he was leading a prayer and received a lukmah. Afterward, some congregants claimed that since he took the correction, he was required to perform sajda al-sahw. They insisted that because he didn't, the prayer was invalid and needed to be repeated.

The Correct Ruling

The author clarifies that this is an incorrect understanding of Islamic jurisprudence. Sajda al-sahw is only required for errors in the wajib (obligatory) parts of the prayer. It has no connection to errors in recitation. If a person makes a mistake in recitation that is severe enough to invalidate the prayer, sajda al-sahw will not fix it; the prayer must be repeated entirely. However, if the error is minor, or if the Imam corrects a major error with the help of a lukmah and continues the prayer correctly, the prayer remains valid. In this case, neither repeating the prayer nor performing sajda al-sahw is necessary.

The author notes that this misconception likely stems from a lack of knowledge among the general public and expresses his intention to write more on the rulings of sajda al-sahw in a future article.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, March 2012, www.alkawsar.com

A Grave Religious Innovation and Severe Misconception

Is There a Third Eid in Islam?

The text addresses the practice of celebrating a new Eid, likely referring to Eid Milad-un-Nabi (the Prophet's birthday), and identifies it as a grave religious error.

The Mistaken Belief and the Islamic View

The author argues that celebrating an invented Eid is a serious mistake for several reasons:

  • Violation of Religious Principles: In Islam, Eids are not optional or rational observances; they are entirely dependent on the clear instructions of Allah and His Messenger (PBUH). Inventing a new Eid is considered a bid'ah (a religious innovation).

  • False Measure of Love: This new Eid is presented as a symbol of love for the Prophet (PBUH). The author refutes this, stating that true love for the Prophet (PBUH) is measured by following his Sunnah, living according to his excellent example (Uswah Hasanah), and striving to eliminate religious innovations, not by celebrating a fabricated festival.

  • Ideological Distortion: Although this practice may seem harmless, it is a profound ideological distortion. The author also points out that the processions (jashne julūs) and other baseless acts performed during these celebrations further compound the error.

  • Focus on Deeds and Piety: The author reminds readers that Allah accepts sincere deeds (amal) and taqwa (piety), not external showmanship. Only following the Sunnah is acceptable to Allah, not bid'ah.

  • Following Foreign Customs: The author questions whether a practice adopted from a culture, such as that of Christians (whose ways Muslims pray to be guided away from in Surah al-Fatihah), can truly benefit the Muslim community.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, March 2012, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Religious Ruling:

Are Children Excluded from Their Father's Inheritance if They Have a Different Mother?

The text addresses the mistaken belief that children from different wives of the same father are not all entitled to an equal share of his inheritance.

The Right to a Father's Inheritance

  • The Misconception: Some people believe that if a father has children with multiple wives, the children from different mothers are not entitled to the inheritance.

  • The Correct Ruling: The author clarifies that this is absolutely wrong. All legitimate children of the deceased father, regardless of whether they have the same mother or different mothers, are entitled to an equal share of the inheritance. The share is distributed according to the fixed proportions set by Islamic law.

The author cites the principle from the Quran, "For the male, the share of two females" (لِلذَّكَرِمِثْلُحَظِّالْأُنْثَيَيْنِ), as the guiding rule for all children.

The Right to a Mother's Inheritance

Similarly, a related misconception is that only the children from a mother's last husband are entitled to her inheritance. The author states that this is also false. All of a mother's children, from any of her husbands, are equally entitled to her inheritance without any distinction.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, April 2012, www.alkawsar.com

A Baseless Idea

Is "Muttalib" One of the Names of Allah?

The text addresses the mistaken belief that "Muttalib" is a divine name of Allah, which would make the name "Abdul Muttalib" (Servant of Muttalib) permissible, similar to "Abd al-Rahman" (Servant of the Most Merciful).

The History and the Misconception

The author recounts the story of the Prophet Muhammad's (PBUH) grandfather. His real name was Shayba. After his father, Hashim, died, his uncle Muttalib brought him back to Makkah from Madinah. As they entered, people who didn't know the truth assumed Muttalib had purchased a slave, so they started calling Shayba "Abdul Muttalib," meaning "slave of Muttalib." Although Muttalib clarified that Shayba was his nephew, the name stuck and became famous.

The author explains that people who are unaware of this history and do not have a proper understanding of the Asma al-Husna (the beautiful names of Allah) sometimes name their children Abdul Muttalib. They do so because they mistakenly believe that Muttalib is one of Allah's names.

The Correct Ruling

The text clarifies that this idea is incorrect. "Muttalib" is not one of the names of Allah. Therefore, naming a child "Abdul Muttalib" is not permissible in Islam.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, April 2012, www.alkawsar.com

A Baseless Notion

Does the punishment of the grave stop until the Day of Judgment if a Friday or Ramadan arrives after burial?

May Allah protect us from the punishment of the grave. May Allah forgive all believing men and women, grant everyone freedom from the punishment of the Barzakh (the period between death and the Day of Judgment), and make all the stages of the afterlife easy and safe for them to pass.

The punishment of the grave is real. It is proven by the Quran and Hadith. The first condition for salvation from this punishment is faith (Iman). The second condition is to live according to the demands of faith, especially by strictly avoiding the sins for which punishment in the grave is mentioned, and by performing with importance those acts for which freedom from the punishment of the grave has been promised.

The point I wish to make here is that some people can be heard saying that when a Friday or Ramadan arrives after the burial of a person who was destined for punishment in the grave due to their sins, their punishment is halted until the Day of Judgment.

Some people even cite Ahsanul Fatawa as a reference for this claim.

In reality, this notion is baseless. Such a claim is not proven by any authentic Hadith or any source of Islamic law. Although such a statement exists in Ahsanul Fatawa (4/208), the supplement of Ahsanul Fatawa, meaning its tenth volume (pages: 433-435), discusses this topic in detail with evidence and proof, and it states that the previous claim is baseless.

Therefore, one should refrain from believing and spreading this baseless claim. One should always be engaged in efforts to make one's grave and afterlife as beautiful as possible. May Allah grant us the ability to do so. Amen.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, April 2012, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Misconception

Is it necessary to sleep after reciting the Du'a for Istikhara?

The word istikhara means to seek goodness, not to be informed about goodness. Therefore, the reality of istikhara is to perform two rak'ahs (units) of nafl (voluntary) prayer and then recite the du'a taught in the Hadith regarding a matter one intends to do (after careful consideration and consultation). The essence of the du'a is, "O Allah! If this matter is good for me, then make it easy for me and grant me blessings in it. But if it is not suitable for me, then turn me away from it, lead me to where goodness lies, and grant me the ability to be content with it."

According to the authentic Hadith, this is the reality of istikhara. However, some people think that the istikhara prayer and du'a must be performed before going to sleep. They also believe that the result of the istikhara—whether the task should be done or not—is conveyed through a dream. This is undoubtedly a baseless idea. One might see a dream after istikhara, but dreams can also be seen without it. If something is seen in a dream, it must be judged based on the rules of Shari'ah concerning dreams. The course of action, in this case, must be determined according to the relevant Shari'ah ruling. And everyone knows that dreams are not a source of evidence.

Another mistake related to istikhara is following the method mentioned in some unreliable books of du'a and wazifa. However, there is no sense in adopting someone's experience or invention by abandoning the prescribed method of istikhara.

A newly invented and bid'ah (innovative) method of istikhara is to seek a sign from the Quran, or from Diwan-e-Hafiz, Masnavi, etc. This is a completely wrong method. And seeking such a sign from the Holy Quran is essentially a sign of disrespect towards it.

Another mistake is having someone else perform istikhara for you. Many people request the mosque's Imam or a familiar aalim (scholar) to do istikhara for them. However, the Hadith says that the person in need should perform the istikhara themselves.

The most dangerous delusion is that some people go to un-Islamic soothsayers not only to decide on a matter but also to find out various hidden things, and they call this istikhara. They even believe what these people say. However, going to someone to know the unseen and believing their words is a form of shirk (associating partners with Allah).

May Allah protect us from all kinds of shirk. Amen.

(For more details, study: Al-Madkhal, Ibn al-Hajj 4/36-40; Hayatul Hayawan 3/38; Ithaf al-Sadat al-Muttaqin, Murtada Zabidi 2/285. The article in the Urdu Da'irah Ma'arif Islamia, Lahore (2/571-573) is also good.)

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, May 2012, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Mistake

Is it Mustahab (Recommended) to Recite Salat, Salam, Dhikr, or Tasbih Before the Adhan?

I don't recall if this topic was published in Al Kawsar before, but I felt the need to write about it again. The new campus of Markazud Da'wah Al-Islamiyah Dhaka is located in Hazratpur, Keraniganj. There, in some nearby mosques, a practice was observed where the mu'adhdhin (caller to prayer) recites tasbih, du'a, na't, or at least durud sharif (blessings upon the Prophet) over the microphone at the time of the adhan, and only then does he say the first takbir of the adhan. This is usually heard during the Maghrib adhan, and in some places, during the Fajr adhan as well.

This is a newly invented practice. It had no existence during the three best generations of Islam (Khayr al-Qurun), or even for several centuries after that. It is explicitly mentioned in Musannaf Ibn Abi Shaybah that the beginning of the adhan is the takbir: "Allahu Akbar, Allahu Akbar."

This is the method that has been followed since the time of the Prophet. The Hadith mentions three actions: responding to the adhan, reciting durud after the adhan, and then reciting a du'a. These are personal actions. The mu'adhdhin will also recite the durud and du'a after the adhan, but privately and in a low voice—not loudly and not over the microphone.

Adopting this newly invented practice while abandoning the method of the Hadith and the continuously transmitted Sunnah is a mistake. It is a form of bid'ah (innovation). The adhan is a symbol and sign of Islam. Any change or addition to a symbol or sign is a highly reprehensible act.

In some areas of the Barelwi community, it is seen that they start every adhan with durud sharif, using the words "As-Salatu Was-Salamu Alaika Ya Rasulallah" (Peace and blessings be upon you, O Messenger of Allah). This durud is permissible to recite during the visitation of the Prophet's tomb (Rawdah athar) but not for general situations. On the one hand, they have added durud sharif to the adhan on their own accord. On the other hand, they have added a durud that is not meant to be recited in all situations.

May Allah grant us the fortune of following the Prophet's Sunnah along with our love for him. If a newly invented method is preferred over the Sunnah and example of the beloved one, what kind of love is that?!

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, May 2012, www.alkawsar.com

Common Mistakes

Some Mistakes Regarding Divorce

In this issue, it seemed appropriate to discuss only this topic. It has been written many times, and scholars and religious leaders also discuss it, that just as it is not permissible for a husband to give a divorce without extreme necessity (which is considered a valid excuse in Shari'ah), it is also not appropriate for a wife to ask for one. The path of divorce has been left open only for use in cases of extreme necessity. It is not necessary to explain how much turmoil, chaos, oppression, and conflict an incident of divorce causes in a family in modern society, especially in our region. Using the power of divorce outside the guidelines prescribed by Shari'ah is undoubtedly an act of frivolity with the laws of Allah.

Therefore, anyone who tries to enter married life has an essential duty to learn the necessary rulings of married life, including the laws of divorce, before getting married.

Divorce is an extremely sensitive matter. If someone misuses this power or applies it in a wrong way, they will not only be a sinner, but the divorce will also take effect. Therefore, it is the responsibility of every sensible husband to carefully refrain from uttering the word 'divorce' or any of its synonyms.

However, if one is compelled to give a divorce due to extreme necessity, one should give only a single divorce to the wife in a state of purity (when she is not menstruating). He should say, "I divorce you." He should not use the word 'ba'in' (irrevocable) or the number '3' with the divorce. If someone says the word 'ba'in' (whether it's one or two divorces), the way to reunite with the wife will be closed without a new, Shari'ah-compliant marriage.

Similarly, if three divorces are given—whether they are given separately in the same sitting or with a single word, for example, by saying, "I give you three divorces," or if two divorces were given before and now only one divorce is given, making a total of three—if three divorces are given in any way, the marital relationship completely ends. In this situation, there is no opportunity to take the wife back merely by verbal means, nor is the path open to remarrying her.

Giving three divorces at once or giving divorces at different times until they total three is a heinous crime and a detestable act. As a punishment for this, Allah has legislated that if they wish to live together again as husband and wife, it is essential for the wife to complete her waiting period (iddah), marry another man, and have intimacy with him. Afterwards, if she is divorced for any reason or her husband dies, they can, after she completes her waiting period, re-enter into a marriage contract if they both agree.

For this reason, Shari'ah has warned in advance: first, do not even think about divorce. However, if there is a need to give a divorce due to extreme necessity, give only a simple divorce—just one divorce. This allows both parties to have an opportunity to rethink and the path to returning remains open. If a problem arises again, give only one more divorce. The path to returning will still be open.

But if after this, another single divorce is given, and the total reaches three, then in this situation, there will be no opportunity to take her back, and the legality of a new marriage will also be gone.

Nowadays, instead of learning the laws of divorce and acting accordingly, husbands and wives hold so many wrong and fabricated rulings in their minds, may Allah forgive us.

1. Does divorce not occur without three divorces?

For example, some people think that giving only one or two divorces does not constitute a divorce. They consider it essential to give three divorces at once for a divorce to be effective.

Remember, this idea is completely wrong. The correct method of giving a divorce is to give only one divorce. If needed again later, give only one divorce. Do not give more than that. But if three divorces are given, all paths to maintaining their marital relationship will be closed.

Giving three divorces in the same sitting or with the same word is haram (forbidden) and a major sin. But if someone does this, the divorce will be effective, and their marital relationship will completely end.

2. Is it necessary to use the word 'ba'in' with divorce?

Many people think that divorce does not occur by just saying 'divorce'; rather, it is essential to add the word 'ba'in' with it.

This is also a wrong idea. Divorce takes effect just by the word 'divorce.' There is no need to add the word 'ba'in' to it. Furthermore, the addition of this word is impermissible. However, if someone gives one 'ba'in' divorce or two 'ba'in' divorces, they have closed the path of verbally taking the wife back. Now, only one path remains open, which is to perform a new, Shari'ah-compliant marriage. In contrast, by just saying 'divorce,' the path of verbal reconciliation remains open for up to two divorces. Therefore, a husband should, no matter how angry he is, never give three divorces. He should not even utter it. Yet, some people even add the word 'ba'in' after giving three divorces, as if giving all the divorces was not enough for them. Otherwise, what is left to say 'ba'in' after giving three divorces?!

Remember, giving three divorces is one sin, and by adding the word 'ba'in,' he becomes even more sinful.

3. Does divorce not occur if three divorces are given at once?

Some people have also spread the misconception that if three divorces are given at once, divorce does not occur or only one divorce occurs.

This is also a serious mistake. Even though giving three divorces at once is not permissible, if someone does this impermissible act, three divorces do indeed fall upon his wife. In this case, his right to verbally take her back is not preserved. They cannot even become halal for each other again by performing a new marriage. Therefore, it is the duty of all husbands to be extremely careful from the very beginning. Never utter the words 'three divorces' or 'divorce, divorce, divorce.' And if two divorces have already been given, do not even think about a third one now.

4. Does divorce not take effect if given during pregnancy?

Some people have fabricated this rule that if a wife is given a divorce while she is pregnant, it does not take effect. This is also a completely baseless statement. Whether the divorce is given during pregnancy or in any other condition, it takes effect. Therefore, it is everyone's responsibility to learn the correct rulings. A forbidden thing can never become permissible due to the deception of ignorance.

5. Is the presence of witnesses necessary for a divorce to take effect?

Some people think that if a husband does not have any witnesses at the time of divorce, the divorce does not take effect. Like the previous one, this is also a man-made ruling. It is unknown which ignorant person said this. The need for witnesses is at the time of marriage. For a divorce to take effect, no witness, whether one or more, is necessary. Even if a husband gives a divorce alone in the dark of night, the divorce still takes effect.

6. Does divorce not occur if given in a state of anger?

Divorce is usually given out of anger. How many people give a divorce calmly? In fact, it should be that if a marital relationship has to be severed due to a realistic and unavoidable need, then one should consult with elders, wish well for each other, and sever the marital relationship by understanding and learning the correct rulings and acting accordingly.

But alas! Most people do not even try to learn the rulings, nor do they have the good sense to consult with elders and reflect on the matter. When they face something against their will, they give a divorce in a fit of anger. And it's not just one or two; it's three divorces in one breath.

When the anger subsides, they feel remorse and start inventing different excuses. They say, "I said it in a fit of rage; I didn't intend to give a divorce." These people should know that intention is not needed for a divorce to take effect. It is not an act of worship that requires intention. Whether there is intention or not, if the word 'divorce' is uttered or written on a paper, divorce takes place. Similarly, divorce given in a state of anger also takes effect, and even if a divorce is given jokingly or in jest, it takes effect.

However, if someone becomes so extremely angry that they lose consciousness and do not remember what they said in that state, the divorce in that condition will not be effective.

The final point is that married life is a great and special blessing from Allah. It is the duty of both the husband and wife to properly value this blessing and fulfill each other's rights. It is not appropriate for a wife to ask her husband for a divorce at every turn. Similarly, it is not permissible for a husband to misuse the power given to him by Allah.

It is essential for both the husband and wife to learn all the rulings and laws of marriage, divorce, and married life. It is especially the duty of the husband never to utter the word 'divorce' without being aware of its rulings and consequences. And if, for any reason, a divorce is given in such a way that it is no longer permissible for them to live together according to Shari'ah, then they should fear Allah. They should not live together by taking refuge in various tricks, excuses, or based on false information, or by concealing the original incident. Marriage is not a matter of a moment; it is a matter for an entire lifetime.

If a divorce has truly taken place and the marital relationship has ended in the eyes of Shari'ah, but they still live together as husband and wife, it will be a major sin, and they will both be involved in the sin of adultery.

May Allah protect everyone and grant them piety and purity. Amen.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, June 2012, www.alkawsar.com

A Serious Mistaken Practice

Making a non-evidence into an evidence

What the sources of Islamic law (Shari'ah) are, and what rulings can be proven by which type of evidence, is a crucial subject in religion and Shari'ah. Its determination has been made based on the Quran and Sunnah. Most Muslims are aware of how many and what the sources of Shari'ah are. However, the people of bid'ah (innovation) and batil (falsehood) always invent new types of evidence. This is so they don't have to struggle to present evidence and proof for their innovations and falsehoods. Nowadays, ignorance has spread so widely that even well-educated people are seen falling victim to astonishing misconceptions. For instance, to narrate something as a Hadith or a story of a prophet, it is considered sufficient to have merely heard it from a storyteller or found it in a book. They don't even feel the need to check whether that narration or story is in a reliable book of Hadith, if it has a chain of narration (sanad), and if the chain is authentic.

If a person cannot investigate themselves, it is still crucial to at least check if an aalim (scholar) who is considered a reliable expert in Hadith has declared it acceptable and fit for narration.

Trying to propagate something without any investigation, just because it is found in some book or pamphlet, should not be the work of a sensible and responsible person.

The rule of Shari'ah is that for a narration to be acceptable, it must be recognized and respected by experts in the science of narration (Ilm al-riwayah). At a minimum, it must be narrated with an acceptable chain in a reliable book. Its popularity and prevalence among the common people have no validity. Similarly, a citation or an unverified narration from an irresponsible author or one who did not stipulate conditions for authenticity is not reliable. Most fabricated and baseless narrations are written in some book, but does that automatically make them acceptable? Na'udhu Billah (We seek refuge in Allah).

It should be remembered that if an unverified narration is not only without a sanad but also munkar (objectionable), and its content has something that is objectionable from the perspective of Shari'ah, or if it contains something that undermines the status and dignity of a sinless person, then it is an even more serious sin to narrate it in sermons and advice or to write it in books of practice.

In one issue of Al Kawsar, such an unsubstantiated, fabricated, and objectionable narration was called false and baseless. And because it was munkar, it was stated that it is not permissible to hold such a belief. One brother called and said, "How can it be impermissible to narrate that narration or to hold that belief? So-and-so person mentioned it!" But those "so-and-so" people were neither experts in the science of narration nor had they adopted the policy of verifying every narration and including only acceptable ones in their books.

Therefore, if a narration is written as baseless based on the citation of experts in Ilm al-riwayah, and there is no contrary decision from another expert in the same field, then it is a mistake to reject it just by saying, "so-and-so person wrote it."

Hakim al-Ummat Thanwi (may Allah have mercy on him) said in 'At-Taqashshuf', "Since those 'so-and-so' people were not aware that this narration was baseless, they will be excused. But after the correct information from the experts is presented to you, you will no longer be excused. It is not permissible for you to follow those 'so-and-so' people in this matter now."

We should always remember this statement of Hakim al-Ummat. The story about Prophet Zakariya (peace be upon him) that was written about in Al Kawsar is an Israelite narration. Moreover, some storytellers have added to it that—na'udhu Billah—because Prophet Zakariya (peace be upon him) sought refuge in a tree instead of Allah, Allah was displeased with him. And when the saw started to cut him and he said "Uhh!", Allah announced, "If you say 'Uhh,' your name will be removed from the list of prophethood!!" Na'udhu Billah.

This added part is not found in any Israelite narration. The question is, if it is said that it is impermissible to believe this fabricated and baseless thing, would you object to that as well?

It is regrettable that one elder wrote a letter saying, "Such and such a verse in 'Pand Nama' alludes to this incident. And the Bengali translator has mentioned that incident in its annotation."

It is a pity that he has made the allusion in Pand Nama a standard for determining authenticity. However, it is not necessary that he or the translator correctly understood the poet's allusion. Who does not know that while one can take advice from the books of Attar (may Allah have mercy on him), a narration cannot be called authentic just because it is mentioned in his book? To determine its authenticity, one must inquire with the scholars of Hadith and act accordingly. In this context, the warning of Hakim al-Ummat Thanwi (may Allah have mercy on him), mentioned in the book 'Ta'limuddin,' should be heeded with great importance.

If we do not act according to this guidance, what will be the difference between us and the people of bid'ah?

This statement of Shaykhul Islam Hazrat Madani (may Allah have mercy on him) is also worthy of being written in golden letters. In a long letter, he wrote, "In matters of rulings, reverence should not be given a place. One should thoroughly verify and investigate."

May Allah grant us the ability to follow in the footsteps of our pious predecessors, who were guided, followers of the Sunnah, and lovers of investigation.

Abu Abdur Rashid Muhammad Abdul Malek

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, July-August 2012, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Religious Ruling

Does Changing a Name Require Repeating the Aqiqah?

The provided text addresses the misconception that if a person's name is changed, a new Aqiqah (a sacrifice for a newborn) must be performed.

The Correct Ruling

The author states that while it is necessary to change an incorrect or inappropriate name, it is not necessary to perform a new Aqiqah when the name is changed. The initial Aqiqah is sufficient. A new one is neither required nor recommended (mustahab). The author clarifies that the original Aqiqah is enough to fulfill the religious obligation.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, September 2012, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Practice

Is it necessary to 'gift' (bakhshana) a recitation of the Quran?

I don't remember if I have written about this before. I have seen in villages and some people have also called and informed me that it is a common practice, especially among women, to make sure to inform the mosque's Imam after they have completed a recitation of the Quran during Ramadan, saying, "So-and-so has completed a recitation, please 'gift' it (bakhshana)!" In some places, there is also a practice of sending some hadiya (gift) along with this message.

There are many aspects of this practice that are objectionable. For example:

  • a. Reciting the Quran is a self-sufficient act of worship. It is not necessary, nor is there any rule, that if someone completes a recitation, it must be 'gifted.' Yes, if someone wants to convey the reward of a good deed to a deceased Muslim, they are allowed to do so. However, this is neither restricted to reciting the Quran nor limited to the month of Ramadan. Furthermore, it is not appropriate to give a permissible act the same importance as an obligatory one.

  • b. For conveying the reward, the intention before or after the act is sufficient. For example, intending that the act is being done on behalf of so-and-so. The story claims that Prophet Sulaiman (AS) asked Allah to allow him to feed every living creature for one day. Though Allah initially refused, He eventually granted permission for one day. Sulaiman (AS) then ordered the jinn and humans to gather all the food and halal animals on Earth. They cooked the food and spread it across a vast field that took two months to travel. A gigantic sea creature then emerged and ate all the food by itself, after which it asked for more. The creature said that Allah provides it three times that amount every day. Overwhelmed, Sulaiman (AS) fell into prostration.

Why It Is Baseless

The author provides several reasons why this story is a fabrication:

  • Inappropriate for a Prophet: A prophet of Allah would not make such a bizarre and illogical request, as it suggests a lack of understanding about Allah's creation. Such a notion is unbecoming of a prophet.

  • Contradicts Logic: It's illogical for a prophet to insist on such a request after being denied by Allah, and it's equally improbable for Allah to permit such an absurd undertaking.

  • Violates Natural Laws: The story suggests that all creatures, including sea animals, would eat cooked food, which is not true.

  • Unbelievable Details: The claim that a single fish could eat a two-month-long stretch of food in an instant is impossible and defies all logic.

  • Lacks Basic Knowledge: The idea that cooked food can be preserved from spoilage simply by air flow is scientifically incorrect.

Conclusion

The author warns against spreading or believing such baseless and illogical stories. He stresses that one should not repeat stories heard from others without proper verification.

"The ‘Arsh (Throne) is Honored by Your Sandal"

يَا مُحَمَّدُ! لَا تَخْلَعْ نَعْلَيْكَ، فَإِنَّ الْعَرْشَ يَتَشَرَّفُ بِقُدُومِكَ مُتَنَعِّلًا وَيَفْتَخِرُ عَلَى غَيْرِهِ مُتَبَرِّكًا.

"O Muhammad! Do not remove your sandals. (Ascend with your sandals on) For the ‘Arsh shall be honored by your arrival with your sandals, and it shall boast over others on account of this blessing."

These words are famous among the common people, and are even heard from some speakers. However, they are not proven. They are all fabricated and made-up stories.

Imam Radīuddīn al-Qazwīnī (R.A.) was asked whether the narration of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) ascending the ‘Arsh with his sandals and Allah Almighty’s address (O Muhammad! The ‘Arsh is honored by your sandals) is proven. He replied:

أَمَّا حَدِيْثُ وَطْئِ النَّبِيِّ صَلَّى اللهُ عَلَيْهِ وَسَلَّمَ الْعَرْشَ بِنَعْلِهِ فَلَيْسَ بِصَحِيْحٍ وَلَا ثَابِتٍ، بَلْ وُصُوْلُهُ إِلَى ذِرْوَةِ الْعَرْشِ لَمْ يَثْبُتْ فِي خَبَرٍ صَحِيْحٍ وَلَا حَسَنٍ وَلَا ثَابِتٍ أَصْلًا، إِنَّمَا صَحَّ فِي الْأَخْبَارِ انْتِهَاؤُهُ إِلَى سِدْرَةِ الْمُنْتَهَى فَحَسْبُ.

"The Hadith of the Prophet (ﷺ) stepping on the ‘Arsh with his sandals is neither sound (Ṣaḥīḥ) nor authentic (Thābit). Moreover, his reaching the peak of the ‘Arsh has not been established in any authentic (Ṣaḥīḥ), good (Ḥasan), or original authentic report. What is authentically established in the reports is only his ascension up to Sidratul Muntaha (the Lote Tree of the Utmost Boundary)." (Subulul Hudā war Rashād - Sharḥul Mawāhib 8/223)

Another Hadith scholar commented:

"May Allah destroy the one who says he ascended the ‘Arsh with his sandals. What insolence! What audacity!! Such a claim about the Chief of the Courteous and the Leader of the Gnostics (‘Ārifīn)! He further stated that Radīuddīn al-Qazwīnī’s answer is correct. The event of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ)'s Mi'raj (ascension to the higher heavens) has been narrated in brief and in detail by about forty Companions, yet none of their reports mention that he had sandals on his feet that night. This claim has only appeared in the poetry of some ignorant storytellers. ... There is no Hadith, neither from a reliable source nor a weak one, which states that he ascended the ‘Arsh. This is a fabricated statement and should be ignored." (Sharḥul Mawāhib 8/223)

Ahmad ibn Muḥammad al-Maqqarī (R.A.), in his book Fatḥul Muta'āl fī Madḥi Khayrin Ni'āl, declared the above statement to be forged (Zal). (Al-Athārul Marfū'ah 37)

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, April 2013, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Mistake

Using Rosewater and Incense for Blessings

The text addresses the mistaken practice of using rosewater in the morning and incense sticks (agarbati) in the evening in shops and businesses to attract barakah (blessings).

The Misconception and the Correct Islamic Approach

The author states that this is a baseless practice. Rosewater is simply a fragrant liquid, and incense is a fragrant smoke, and neither has any connection to divine blessings.

The author explains that barakah comes from Allah alone. The primary way to receive blessings is by showing gratitude (shukriya) for Allah's favors and by making dua for blessings. Allah Himself promises in the Quran (Surah Ibrahim, 14:7), "If you are grateful, I will surely increase you [in favor]."

A believer should seek blessings through righteous deeds and by showing gratitude in the morning and evening. The author provides a dua taught by the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) for this purpose:

For the morning:

اللهم ما أصبح بي من نعمة أو بأحد من خلقك، فمنك وحدك لا شريك لك، فلك الحمد ولك الشكر.

For the evening, a slight change is made:

اللهم ما أمسى بي

The meaning of the dua is: "O Allah, whatever blessing has come to me or to any of Your creation in this morning (or evening), it is from You alone, You have no partner. All praise is for You, and all thanks are for You."

The author concludes that true believers should seek blessings by following the teachings of the religion and being grateful, not through empty rituals.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, May 2013, www.alkawsar.com

Another Baseless Statement

Will the Prophet (ﷺ) Faint in Three Places on the Day of Judgment? (Na'uzubillah)

When describing the terror of the Mizan (Scale), the Scroll of Deeds (Amalnamah), and the Pul-Sirat (Bridge), some people have been heard saying that the situation in these three places will be so dreadful that even the Prophet (ﷺ) will faint in these three spots (Na'uzubillah - we seek refuge in Allah).

This statement has absolutely no basis. Saying such a thing is a grievous sin.

On the contrary, the Hadith states: Anas (R.A.) said, "I requested the Prophet (ﷺ) to intercede for me on the Day of Resurrection. The Prophet (ﷺ) said, 'Yes, I will intercede for you.' I asked, 'O Messenger of Allah! Where should I look for you (on that Day)?' The Prophet replied, 'First, look for me near the (Pul) Sirat.' I asked, 'What if I do not meet you there?' He said, 'Then look for me near the Mizan (Scale).' I asked, 'What if I do not find you there either?' The Prophet replied, 'Then look for me near the Hawz (the Hawd al-Kawthar). For I will surely be at one of these three places on that day.'" (Jami' Tirmidhi, Hadith: 2433; Musnad Ahmad, Hadith: 12825)

The Prophet (ﷺ) will not faint even in a situation more difficult than this. On the Plain of Gathering (Hashar), when Allah Almighty will be in a state of severe wrath, people will go to the great Prophets seeking intercession, and all will express their inability. Finally, when they come to the Prophet (ﷺ), he will intercede (Details in: Jami' Tirmidhi, Hadith: 2434; Sahih Bukhari, Hadith: 3340).

Yes, it is true that the condition of mankind in these places will be very critical and frightening. But the claim that the Prophet (ﷺ) will faint in these three places is entirely baseless.

May Allah protect us from uttering fabricated statements.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, May 2013, www.alkawsar.com

A Baseless Statement

The Prostration (Sujūd) in the World of Souls (Ālam-e-Arwāḥ)

I heard a person say that in the World of Souls (Ālam-e-Arwāḥ), Allah commanded His servants to perform prostration (Sujūd). They claimed that those who prostrated first will be unbelievers (Kāfir) in this world. Those who prostrated in the middle will be moderate or middle-ground believers in this world. And those who prostrated at the end will initially be Kāfir but later become believers (Īmāndār) and enter Paradise (Jannah).

This is an absolutely fantastical and baseless statement. No sensible person would utter it, let alone believe it. There is no mention anywhere in the Qur'an or Hadith that Allah commanded His servants to prostrate in the Ālam-e-Arwāḥ. Therefore, neither saying nor believing such a thing is correct.

Yes, it is true that Allah took a covenant or affirmation from His servants in the Ālam-e-Arwāḥ, the description of which is clearly mentioned in the Qur'an and Hadith. This is mentioned in Surah Al-A'raf, verse 172: (Translation) "And [remember] when your Lord brought forth from the children of Adam—from their loins—their descendants and made them testify concerning themselves, [saying to them], 'Am I not your Lord?' They said, 'Yes, we have testified.'..."

The details of this affirmation have also come in the Hadith.

May Allah protect us from uttering and believing in fabricated statements.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, May 2013, www.alkawsar.com

This is Not a Hadith

Satan Fasts on the Day of Eid

Some people are heard quoting this statement as a Hadith. However, it is neither a Hadith nor a statement from any Hadith. Fasting on the Day of Eid is forbidden (Nishiḍḍha); therefore, fasting on the day of Eid is a devilish act (Shayṭānī Kāj). It is likely from this context that some people said, "Satan fasts on the Day of Eid," and later, someone narrated it as a Hadith.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, May 2013, www.alkawsar.com

This is Not a Hadith

Jibril's Four Questions... Are You Greater or Is the Deen Greater?

It is heard among people that once Jibril (A.S.) questioned the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ):

  1. Are you greater or am I greater? The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "I am greater, because you are sent to me."

  2. Are you greater or is the Qur'an greater? The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "I am greater, because the Qur'an was revealed to me."

  3. Are you greater or is the 'Arsh (Throne) greater? The Prophet (ﷺ) said, "I am greater, because I was told to ascend the 'Arsh with my sandals on."

  4. Are you greater or is the Deen (Religion) greater? The Prophet (ﷺ) replied, "The Deen is greater, because I was sent for the Deen."

This is neither a Hadith nor a statement from any Hadith. The status of Jibril, the Qur'an, the 'Arsh, and the Deen are each established in their own place. Comparing one of them to another or comparing the status of any of them to the Prophet (ﷺ) is an entirely futile exercise that is not befitting for any believer. It has no connection to faith (Iman) or deeds (Amal).

Moreover, this narration is a compilation of other fabricated narrations, which proves beyond a doubt that it is a forgery. For instance, it contains the statement about the Prophet (ﷺ) ascending the 'Arsh with his sandals on, which is unanimously considered fabricated and baseless (A detailed discussion on this appeared in the 'Incorrect Notion' section of Al Kawsar, April 2013).

Therefore, it is obligatory (Farḍ) to refrain from uttering such ignorant and baseless statements of the Age of Ignorance (Jahiliyyah).

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, June-July 2013, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Mistake:

Saying "How Are You?" Before Answering the Greeting of Salam

The text addresses the mistaken practice of responding to the Islamic greeting of peace (salam) with "How are you?" instead of first returning the greeting.

Why It's a Mistake

The author notes that many people, upon being greeted, either fail to respond to the salam or respond vaguely before quickly asking, "How are you?" The author clarifies that responding to a salam is wajib (a necessary and obligatory act). Therefore, the correct procedure is to clearly and audibly return the greeting first, and only then proceed with a conversation or ask about the other person's well-being.

Failing to properly return the salam and rushing to ask "How are you?" is considered highly inappropriate and a violation of Islamic etiquette.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, June-July 2013, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Religious Ruling

Is It Necessary to Make a Verbal Intention for Fasting?

The text addresses the mistaken belief that a person must make a verbal intention for their fast (niyyah).

The Misconception vs. The Correct Ruling

  • The Mistaken Belief: Many people believe that to validate their fast, they must verbally express the intention, often by reciting a specific Arabic phrase. Some think they must at least say something like, "I intend to fast tomorrow," otherwise their fast will not be valid.

  • The Correct Ruling: The author states that this is completely incorrect. A verbal intention is not necessary for fasting. The intention is an act of the heart, so simply having the resolve to fast in one's heart is sufficient. Furthermore, the act of eating the pre-dawn meal (suhur) with the purpose of fasting automatically serves as the intention. Therefore, the concern that the fast will be invalid without a verbal intention is unfounded.

An Incorrect Religious Ruling (Mas'ala)

Can the Parents Not Eat the Meat from their Child's Aqiqah?

Confusion sometimes arises in certain areas regarding the distribution of the meat from a child's Aqiqah (sacrifice performed upon the birth of a child). Many people hold the notion that the parents are not allowed to eat the Aqiqah meat. Instead, they believe it must be distributed among neighbors, the poor, and the needy (Miskeen).

This notion is incorrect. The Aqiqah meat can be eaten by the parents, family members, relatives, neighbors, or the needy—anyone may partake in it.

(See: Sunan al-Bayhaqī, Vol. 9, p. 302; Musannaf Ibn Abi Shaybah, Hadiths 24739, 24749; I'lā' al-Sunan, Vol. 17, p. 126; Tuhfat al-Mawdūd, p. 78)

A Common Mistake

The Evening Light

The belief that one must turn on the lights in a shop or vehicle when the Maghrib Adhan is called, or else business will suffer, is an incorrect notion. This is referred to as the 'Evening Light' (Shondhar Bati).

This idea is not correct. When evening falls, lights are naturally turned on in shops and vehicles out of necessity; what connection does this have with profit or loss? Profit and loss come only from Allah. Turning the lights on or off has no role here. If there is a need, one should turn on the lights; otherwise, one should not.

An Incorrect Religious Ruling (Mas'ala)

A Woman Seen by Forty Non-Mahram Men in a Day is Considered to be in the Status of a Man

Some people are heard saying, "A woman who is seen by forty non-Mahram men (men not closely related) in a day is considered to be in the status of a man." This statement is perhaps made from the perspective that other women should stay away from such disobedient (Fasiq) women—and that concept is correct. However, to make the sweeping statement that such a woman is "in the status of a man" is incorrect.

A woman is a woman, and all the religious rulings (Ahkam) applicable to women remain applicable to her. Nevertheless, to avoid bad company, one should maintain distance from unbelieving (Kafir), disobedient (Fasiq), and irreligious women.

Furthermore, where is the logic behind the number forty in this context?

It is worth noting that violating Purda (Islamic veil/modesty) is a major sin (Kabira Gunah). Continuously committing this sin is a great transgression. This sin is not limited to the individual alone; it also aids others in committing sin, thereby placing the burden of their sin on the woman as well. The burden of sin becomes heavy. Therefore, it is obligatory (Farḍ) for every man and woman to refrain from this sin.

An Incorrect Practice

Should One First Drop and Then Tie the Hands When Saying the Takbir for Qunut?

Many people are seen first dropping their hands down and then raising and tying them when saying the Takbir (Allahu Akbar) for the Dua-e-Qunut in the Witr prayer. This is not correct. There is no need to drop the hands down before saying the Takbir and tying them.

Many are also seen doing the same in the case of the extra Takbirs of the Eid prayers.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, August 2013, www.alkawsar.com

Distorted Pronunciation of Names

Mehbub, Rehman, Mehmud

Many people pronounce or write these names in this way. Saying or writing them like this is both incorrect. Their correct pronunciations are, respectively, 'Mahbub,' 'Rahman,' and 'Mahmud.' These are Arabic names. The first letter of each name carries a Zabar (Fatha). Pronouncing them in the incorrect way changes the Zabar to a Zēr (Kasra), which is completely wrong.

Moreover, the name 'Rahman' is a Name of Allah. It is used as the second part of a compound name, such as Mahbubur Rahman. Especially since this is a Name of Allah, its distorted pronunciation is a great transgression.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, August 2013, www.alkawsar.com

An Incorrect Custom

Good Omen on the Right, Bad Omen on the Left

Many people throw stones at a bird when they leave their house in the morning. If the bird flies to the right, they believe the journey is auspicious (a good omen). If the bird flies to the left, it is considered inauspicious (a bad omen).

This is a baseless idea that has no foundation. Good fortune and misfortune, profit and loss, all come from Allah. What connection does a bird have with this?! If Allah wills, I will have good fortune, otherwise not.

Islam has strongly rejected this mentality of bad omens. It is declared in a Hadith:

لا عَدْوَى وَلا طِيَرَةَ وَلا هَامَةَ وَلا صَفَرَ

Meaning: "There is no contagion ('adwa), no evil omen (ṭiyarah), no bad omen from an owl (hammah), and no bad omen from the month of Safar." (Ṣaḥīḥ Bukhārī, Hadith: 5707)

Furthermore, it is not wise to needlessly destroy one's morale for the day based on such baseless assumptions.

Therefore, it is the duty of every believer to abandon such unfounded notions. May Allah protect us.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, September 2013, www.alkawsar.com

An Incorrect Practice

Is Praying While Seated on a Chair a Matter of Personal Choice?

For some time, I have been observing a worshipper in the local mosque who prays while seated on a chair when he easily finds one. But if he arrives later or a chair is unavailable, he prays standing.

With the increasing prevalence of chairs in mosques, some people may think that praying while seated on a chair is a matter of personal choice. They seem unaware that there are specific Islamic rulings (Shar'i বিধান) regarding which types of excuses (O'zr) permit praying on a chair, when the prayer is invalid or disliked (Makrūh), and when one must sit on the floor instead of a chair.

Those who have such an excuse should consult a knowledgeable scholar ('Ālim) to present their situation and follow the religious ruling (Mas'ala) correctly. It is wrong to simply decide to pray on a chair due to slight pain or discomfort without realizing that the prayer might not even be valid.

The fundamental rule regarding this is:

For a person unable to pray standing, the alternative method is to perform the prayer sitting on the ground.

For a person unable to perform Rukū' (bowing) and Sujūd (prostration), the alternative is to perform them by gesturing (Ishārā).

For a person unable to pray sitting on the ground, the alternative is to pray sitting on a chair.

Therefore, praying while sitting on a chair is not correct based only on the first or second excuse alone (i.e., being unable to stand or unable to perform Rukū'/Sujūd).

Hence, our duty is to consult a knowledgeable scholar regarding this matter, and any similar issues, instead of making decisions on our own.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, September 2013, www.alkawsar.com

An Incorrect Notion

Is Dua-e-Ma'thura Only 'Allahumma Inni Zalamtu Nafsi...'?

The Dua-e-Ma'thura is recited in the final sitting (Jalsah) of the prayer, after the Darood Shareef. Any one Masnūn Du'a (supplication reported from the Prophet) can be recited here. Multiple Du'as can also be recited. It is stated in the Hadith:

ثُمَّ يَتَخَيَّرُ مِنَ الْمَسْأَلَةِ مَا شَاءَ

(Meaning) "Then he may choose whatever supplication he wishes." (Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim, Hadith: 402)

The Du'a that is most popular in this regard is: 'Allahumma innī zalamtu nafsī...' As a result, many people believe that this is the only Dua-e-Ma'thura. They think that no other Du'a can be recited in this position. In reality, this is not the case. Any Du'a from the Qur'an or Hadith can be recited in this position, and the Sunnah is fulfilled by reciting any Du'a from the Qur'an or Hadith.

It should be noted that the term Dua-e-Ma'thur (plural: Ad'iyyah Ma'thura) means a reported supplication—that is, those Du'as that have been taught in the Holy Qur'an and the Hadith.

Other Du'as are also narrated in the Hadith for recitation at this point. One of them is:

اللَّهُمَّ إِنِّي أَعُوذُ بِكَ مِنْ عَذَابِ الْقَبْرِ، وَأَعُوذُ بِكَ مِنْ فِتْنَةِ الْمَسِيحِ الدَّجَّالِ، وَأَعُوذُ بِكَ مِنْ فِتْنَةِ الْمَحْيَا وَالْمَمَاتِ، اللَّهُمَّ إِنِّي أَعُوذُ بِكَ مِنَ الْمَأْثَمِ وَالْمَغْرَمِ

Meaning: "O Allah, I seek refuge with You from the punishment of the grave, and I seek refuge with You from the trial (Fitnah) of the False Messiah (Masīḥ ad-Dajjāl), and I seek refuge with You from the trial of life and death. O Allah, I seek refuge with You from sin and debt." (Ṣaḥīḥ Bukhārī, Hadith: 832; Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim, Hadith: 589)

The Du'a that is most famous among us was taught by the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) at the request of Abu Bakr (R.A.).

It is reported in a Hadith that Hafsa bint Umar (R.A.) requested the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ), "Teach me a Du'a that I may recite in the prayer." The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said, "Recite this Du'a:

اللَّهُمَّ إِنِّي ظَلَمْتُ نَفْسِي ظُلْمًا كَثِيرًا وَلاَ يَغْفِرُ الذُّنُوبَ إِلاَّ أَنْتَ فَاغْفِرْ لِي مَغْفِرَةً مِنْ عِنْدِكَ وَارْحَمْنِي إِنَّكَ أَنْتَ الْغَفُورُ الرَّحِيمُ

Meaning: "O Allah, indeed I have wronged myself with great wrongdoing, and none forgives sins except You. So forgive me with a forgiveness from Yourself, and have mercy upon me. Surely, You are the Forgiving, the Merciful." (Ṣaḥīḥ Bukhārī, Hadith: 834; Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim, Hadith: 2705)

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, September 2013, www.alkawsar.com

An Incorrect Notion

If Dropped Rice Is Not Eaten, Will It Turn into a Scorpion and Sting in the Grave?

When a small child eats with their own hands, a lot of rice often drops. To encourage the child to pick up and eat the dropped rice, many people say, "Pick up and eat the dropped rice, or else it will turn into a scorpion and sting you in the grave."

It is commendable to caution and encourage children regarding such matters. However, using baseless statements to do so is never appropriate.

The guidance provided in the Hadith regarding this matter should be presented to children instead.

It is narrated from Anas ibn Malik (R.A.) that when the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) ate, he would lick his fingers clean and say, "If a morsel of food falls, remove the dirt from it and eat it, and do not leave it for Satan." He also commanded us to lick the plate clean, saying, "For you do not know in which part of your food the blessing (Barakah) lies." (Ṣaḥīḥ Muslim, Hadith 2034; Sunan Abū Dāwūd, Hadith 3847; Ṣaḥīḥ Ibn Ḥibbān, Hadith 5249)

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, October 2013, www.alkawsar.com

An Incorrect Notion

Considering the Bengali Address Before Jumu'ah as the Khutbah

Before the Jumu'ah (Friday) prayer, the Prophet (ﷺ) used to deliver two sermons (Khutbah). He would sit briefly between the two sermons, and both sermons were in the Arabic language. It is a confirmed Sunnah (Sunnah Mu'akkadah) for both sermons to be in Arabic. This is proven by the Hadith, and the Companions (Sahaba), Successors (Tabi'in), later generations (Tabi' Tabi'in), and the entire Muslim Ummah have acted upon this throughout the ages. For this reason, sermons delivered according to this rule are called the Khutbah Masnūnah (Prophetically Prescribed Sermon).

Because many people gather in the mosque on Friday, this opportunity is utilized to give a religious talk in the local language. This is not considered the Khutbah Masnūnah.

However, some people consider this religious talk given before the sermon to be the actual Jumu'ah Khutbah. Their idea is incorrect. This is because the Jumu'ah Khutbah has some distinct rulings (Ahkam) that are its exclusive characteristics. For example, the Khutbah must be in the Arabic language, and all talking or activities are prohibited during the Khutbah, etc. Therefore, the belief of those who consider the Bengali address before the Jumu'ah Khutbah to be the actual sermon is incorrect.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, October 2013, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistake in Utterance

'Alayhis Sallam'

When pronouncing the name of our Prophet (ﷺ), we say "Sallallahu 'Alayhi Wa Sallam." When pronouncing the names of other Prophets, we say, "'Alayhis Salām." If we mention the names of several Prophets, we say "'Alayhimus Salām."

However, some people cannot differentiate between the words 'Sallam' and 'Salām'. Consequently, in the second case (for other Prophets), they say 'Alayhis Sallam' instead of 'Alayhis Salām', which is completely incorrect.

The correct pronunciation is: The final word in the first phrase is 'Sallam' (Sallallahu 'Alayhi Wa Sallam), and the final word in the second phrase is 'Salām' ('Alayhis Salām).

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, October 2013, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistake in Utterance

Telling a Child: "You are my Lakhshmi!"

Many parents lovingly tell their child, "You are my Lakhshmi!" This is a serious mistake that pollutes one's faith and belief (Aqidah). Such a phrase has essentially spread among Muslims from the Hindus. Lakhshmi is a Hindu goddess whom Hindus consider the deity of wealth, fortune, and good luck.

The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) taught the Ummah the beautiful and unbeautiful choices of words in language. There is no doubt that if a word is associated with polytheism (Shirk), it must be abandoned. Therefore, it is essential to refrain from saying such Hindu-influenced words.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, November 2013, www.alkawsar.com

An Incorrect Custom

Four Quls at the Four Corners of the Grave

In many areas, the custom is that after the deceased (Mayyit) is buried, four people stand at the four corners of the grave and recite the Four Quls (i.e., Surah Al-Kafirun, Al-Ikhlas, Al-Falaq, and An-Nas). Afterwards, they plant four fresh branches at the four corners of the grave.

In some places, they recite the Four Quls while holding four pegs, and then drive the pegs into the four corners of the grave. Elsewhere, they wrap threads around the four pegs. Someone else mentioned that in their area, they recite the Four Quls while holding four twigs, and then place the four twigs on top of the grave.

This is a fabricated custom (Rasm) that has no basis. No evidence for this practice is found in any Hadith or from the Companions (Sahaba) or their Successors (Tabi'in). Therefore, it must be abandoned.

Instead of following such fabricated customs, one should perform proven acts of worship. A Fabricated Tale

The Rooster of Koh-e-Qaf

Koh-e-Qaf is understood to mean a mountain that is supposedly circular, like the Arabic letter Qaf, and completely encircles the entire earth. Upon it sits a gigantic rooster, with one foot on one end of the mountain and the other on the opposite end. This is what is referred to as the 'Rooster of Koh-e-Qaf.'

Some storytellers introduce this tale to explain how Great a Provider (Razzaq) Allah is, saying that Allah is such a great Sustainer that He provides Rizq (sustenance) to this massive rooster regularly.

In reality, this is a fabricated tale that has no basis. Let alone the Rooster of Koh-e-Qaf, even the mountain of Koh-e-Qaf itself has no existence.

In the beginning of the Tafsir (exegesis) of Surah Qaf in Tafsir Ibn Kathir, Ibn Kathir (R.A.) says, "It appears to me that this and similar matters are fabricated by Zindiqs (heretics)." Imam Alusi (R.A.) quotes the statement of Imam Qarafi (R.A.) in Tafsir Ruhul Ma'ani. Imam Qarafi says, "The mountain of Koh-e-Qaf (Jabal-e-Qaf) has no existence." After citing this, Alusi (R.A.) says, "My opinion is also the same." (See: Tafsir Ruhul Ma'ani, Vol. 23, p. 192 [Shamela]). For more details, see: Al-Israiliyyat wal Mawdhoo'at fi Kutubit Tafaseer, Muhammad ibn Muhammad Abu Shahba, pp. 302-304.

There is no need to introduce such baseless stories to explain that Allah is the Great Provider. There are plenty of verses regarding this in the Holy Qur'an.

A person is capable of making any time fruitful and blessed through good and correct actions.

This is Not a Hadith

Angels Stand Outside the Mosque Carrying Sins on Their Heads

O Allah, have mercy on him." (Sahih Bukhari, Hadith: 659). Furthermore, waiting for the next prayer after one prayer results in the forgiveness of sins. (Sahih Muslim, Hadith: 251).

A False Story

The Story of 'Uthman (R.A.)'s Wearing of a Sackcloth

Suyuti (R.A.) says in Al-La'ali al-Masnu'ah (1:269), "This is a fabricated narration forged by Ushnani."

This is the forged narration. However, storytellers often add more details before and after it to make it more sensational. The virtues of Abu Bakr (R.A.) and his acts of charity are narrated in authentic Hadiths. Those are what should be narrated.

This is Not a Hadith

The Fast of Ashura: The Reward of Sixty Years of Worship

Instead of that, the following authentic Hadiths concerning the virtue of Ṣalāh (prayer) can be mentioned:

It is not correct to invent virtues or narrate any baseless matter as a virtue.

May Allah protect us from speaking baseless words.

An Incorrect Notion

Is the Prohibited Time for Prayer at Noon Exactly 12:00 PM?

It is prohibited to pray when the sun is exactly overhead at noon. Many people believe this time is precisely 12:00 PM. This notion is incorrect.

This time span is approximately 5 minutes before the sun passes its zenith (the time of Zawal, when the sun begins to decline). Due to seasonal variations in the time of Zawal, this prohibited period also changes. There can be a difference of about half an hour in the Zawal time depending on the season. In one season (according to Dhaka time), the earliest Zawal time might be 11:42 AM, and in another season, the latest might be 12:13 PM.

Subtracting five minutes from the Zawal time gives the prohibited time for prayer at noon, which ranges from a minimum of 11:37 AM in one season to a maximum of 12:08 PM in another. Therefore, it is incorrect to specifically consider exactly 12:00 PM as the prohibited time for prayer at noon.

In short, the prohibited time for prayer at noon is the five minutes immediately preceding the Zawal time, whenever that may be.

The Arabic text of the Hadith is as follows:

"...من سلك طريقا يبتغي فيه علما، سلك الله به طريقا إلى الجنة، و إن الملائكة لتضع أجنحتها رضى لطالب العلم، و إن العالم ليستغفر له من في السموات و من في الأرض حتى الحيتان في الماء..."

Therefore, one should only quote this and other authentic Hadiths regarding the virtues of the seeker of knowledge.

Note: Some have interpreted the phrase لتضع أجنحتها (latadha'u ajnihatyha) in this Hadith as "spreading the wings." Others have said it means "humbling themselves in honor of the seeker of knowledge." Still others have said it means "stopping flight and descending for remembrance (Dhikr)." Essentially, the phrase allows for all these meanings.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, June-July 2014, www.alkawsar.com

An Incorrect Pronunciation

The Reply to Salam as 'Alaikum Salam'

Many of us unknowingly make mistakes when giving Salam (salutation) or replying to it. Previously (April 2005), various mistakes regarding Salam were written about, focusing on the common pronunciation errors when initiating the Salam. Today, attention is drawn to the pronunciation mistake observed when replying to the Salam.

Salam is a prayer (Dua), an act that is a symbol and rite (Shi'ar) of Islam. It is essential to give importance to its correct pronunciation. At the very least, a clear pronunciation is necessary to ensure the meaning remains intact.

The correct reply is:

وَعَلَيْكُمُ السَّلَامُ وَرَحْمَةُ اللهِ وَبَرَكَاتُهُ

'Wa 'alaikumus Salaam, wa Rahmatullahi, wa Barakatuh'

One should learn the correct pronunciation by looking at the Arabic text; otherwise, a part of the pronunciation gets dropped, and instead of 'Wa 'alaikumus Salaam', it becomes 'Alaikum...', which is a clear mistake. (Note: It is not possible to perfectly convey the correct Arabic pronunciation in Bengali.)

Another point to note is that we often hesitate to give the full reply to the Salam. We don't say the entire answer; instead, we give a perfunctory reply. However, Allah Almighty Himself taught in the Qur'an that when someone gives you a Salam, you should reply to them with a better expression. In Surah An-Nisa, verse 86, Allah Almighty states (Translation): "When you are greeted with a salutation, greet in return with one better than it, or (at least) return it in the same words. Indeed, Allah is Ever a Reckoner of everything."

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, August 2014, www.alkawsar.com

Another Baseless Narration

The Bath on the Night of Shab-e-Barat

There is another baseless narration widespread in society regarding the 15th night of Sha'ban (Shab-e-Barat). It centers on taking a bath on this night. This is Not a Hadith

Making Halwa-Ruti on Shab-e-Barat Will Get You Shade Under the Throne of Allah

It has been heard that almost all the women in a certain village say, "If you make Halwa (sweet dish) and Ruti (bread) on Shab-e-Barat, you will receive shade under the Throne of Allah (Arsh)." This has been stated as a Hadith of the Messenger (ﷺ). However, this statement has not even the remotest connection to the Hadith of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).

This is a baseless statement whose fabrication is beyond any doubt. It cannot be found even in books written about fabricated (Mawdu') Hadiths.

Some people are heard saying that when the Prophet (ﷺ)'s sacred tooth was broken (shaheed) during the Battle of Uhud, he could not eat any hard food for some days. It is claimed that to show sympathy for that event, Halwa and Ruti are elaborately eaten on this day. However, the Battle of Uhud did not happen on the 15th of Sha'ban; it happened on the 7th of Shawwal. Therefore, if there were any connection to that event, it would be on the 7th of Shawwal, not the 15th of Sha'ban.

The virtue of the fifteenth night of Sha'ban (Shab-e-Barat) is proven by authentic (Sahih) Hadith. (For details on the virtues of this night, see the Al Kawsar issue of September 2005 under the title "Sha'ban and Shab-e-Barat in the Grip of Extremism and Negligence"). It is narrated in the Hadith that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "Allah looks at His creation (with mercy) on the night of the middle of Sha'ban (the night between the 14th and 15th of Sha'ban) and forgives everyone except a polytheist (Mushrik) and one who harbors malice (Bid'ah)." (Sahih Ibn Hibban, Hadith 5665; Shu'ab al-Iman, Bayhaqi, Hadith 3833). But what is the connection between this night and Halwa-Ruti?

One should restrict oneself only to the virtues that have been proven for this night. It is not right to fall for customs and traditions (Rasm-Rewaz) and thereby be deprived of its actual virtue.

The matter under discussion is one of the various customs associated with this night and has no basis whatsoever. It is necessary to refrain from such acts and all other customs and traditions centered around this night.

And stating such a baseless claim as a Hadith of the Messenger is a very severe sin. May Allah protect us and grant us the ability to adhere to the authentic word and deed in all matters of the Deen (religion).

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, August 2014, www.alkawsar.com

An Incorrect Notion

Does Allah Benefit If We Worship Him?!

A brother's father was very ill and had been admitted to the ICU, breathing with the aid of oxygen. While visiting his father, the conversation turned to how health is a great blessing (Ni'mat) from Allah, and that one should offer gratitude (Shukriya) for this blessing more often. At one point, the brother said, "If we are healthy, it is Allah's benefit; then we will be able to worship Allah."

(I have heard other people express similar statements.) This is an incorrect notion that arises due to a person's ignorance. What relation does Allah's profit or loss have to our worship? If we perform a good deed, we are the ones who will gain its benefit and reward (Thawab). And the ill-effects and calamity of our disobedience (Nafarmaani) will fall upon us. Our worship or lack thereof will not cause the slightest increase or decrease in Allah's dominion. Allah is not in need of our worship.

In a Hadith Qudsi (Divine Saying), Allah Almighty states: "...O My servants, were the first of you and the last of you, the human of you and the jinn of you, to become as pious as the most pious heart among you, that would not increase My Sovereignty in anything. O My servants, were the first of you and the last of you, the human of you and the jinn of you, to become as wicked as the most wicked heart among you, that would not decrease My Sovereignty in anything..." (Sahih Muslim, Hadith 2577)

Some desert dwellers used to think that by embracing Islam, they were bestowing a favor upon (Allah and) His Prophet. Addressing them, Allah Almighty said (Translation): "They consider it a favor to you that they have accepted Islam. Say, 'Do not regard your acceptance of Islam as a favor to me. Rather, Allah has conferred favor upon you, by guiding you to the faith, if you are truthful.'" (Surah Hujurat 49:17)

Therefore, we must be extremely careful to keep ourselves free from such statements or notions. Allah is the Giver of success (Tawfiq).

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, September 2014, www.alkawsar.com

An Incorrect Idea

Does Licking the Plate Result in a Female Child?

When one brother was encouraged to lick his plate clean, he said, "If you lick the plate, you will have a daughter." Another person commented, "Licking the plate is bad manners and a sign of poverty." (May Allah protect us from such a belief - Na'uzubillah).

Both of these ideas are completely baseless, meaningless, and utter foolishness. There is no doubt that people express such views due to their neglect and ignorance in matters of Deen (religion). This is because the decision to grant children—whether to give someone a son or a daughter—is completely dependent on the will of Allah Almighty. What connection does licking the plate have with this?

Allah Almighty states (Translation): "To Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth; He creates what He wills. He gives to whom He wills female [children], and He gives to whom He wills males. Or He gives them both male and female [children], and He renders whom He wills barren. Indeed, He is Knowing and Competent." (Surah Ash-Shura 42:49-50).

Another harmful aspect of such notions is that they reveal the foul odor of the Age of Ignorance (Jahiliyyah). In the Age of Ignorance, people's faces would turn dark upon hearing the news of a female child (Surah An-Nahl 16:58). Yet, Allah has referred to the news of a daughter as a 'good tiding' (Susangbad).

And perhaps the second gentleman made his comment because he was unaware that licking the plate clean is a Sunnah of the Messenger (ﷺ). Because no one who has even an atom's weight of Iman (faith) would make such a comment after knowing the matter is a Sunnah. What constitutes good manners and etiquette, and what constitutes bad manners and disrespect, must be learned from the Messenger (ﷺ).

Anas (R.A.) narrates that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: "When any one of you eats food, he should lick his fingers. And if a morsel falls, he should remove the dirt from it and eat it, and not leave it for Satan." At the same time, he commanded us to lick the plate clean, saying: "Because you do not know in which part of your food the blessing (Barakah) lies." (Sahih Muslim, Hadith 136; Jami' Tirmidhi, Hadith 1803)

May Allah grant us all correct knowledge (Ilm) and understanding (Samajh). Amin.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, September 2014, www.alkawsar.com

An Incorrect Assumption

Does the Diner Drown If Food Isn't Served Twice on Their Plate?

In some places, it's observed that after serving a person one spoonful of food onto their plate, even if they decline more, a small second spoonful is insisted upon. Along with this, the statement is made, "You shouldn't serve food only once, otherwise you will fall into water and die."

The question is, what connection is there between serving food once or twice on a plate and the place of one's death? The true knowledge of where a person will die rests solely with Allah, the Knower of the Unseen (Alimul Ghayb). Allah Almighty states (Translation): "And no soul knows in what land it will die." (Surah Luqman 31:34)

However, if someone, discarding this erroneous belief that not serving twice leads to drowning, wishes to offer food multiple times out of hospitality (Mehmandari), there is no problem with that. But even in this case, one should avoid artificiality and pay attention to the appetite and desire of the person eating.

A Baseless Story

The Story of Uways al-Qarani Breaking His Teeth

The story of Uways al-Qarani breaking his teeth is very famous among people. The incident is recounted as follows: When the Prophet (ﷺ)'s sacred tooth was broken (shaheed) during the Battle of Uhud, Uways al-Qarani learned of the matter and was extremely distressed. He had immense love for the Prophet (ﷺ). Upon hearing the news, he could not remain calm. He thought, "What good is this tooth of mine when the Prophet's sacred tooth has been broken?" He broke one of his own teeth. Then, he reconsidered, "Perhaps the tooth I broke is not the same one the Prophet (ﷺ)'s was, maybe it was a different tooth." Thinking this, he broke another one of his teeth. In this manner, he broke all of his own teeth.

Various people recount this story in different ways as the ultimate example of a follower's love for the Prophet. However, this story has no basis whatsoever. Mullah Ali Qari (may Allah have mercy on him) stated that this incident is not authenticated. (See: Al-Madin al-Adani, Al-Burhan al-Jali fi Tahqiq Intisab al-Sufiyyat ila Ali, pp. 164-165).

Uways al-Qarani was a great Tabi'i (successor to the Companions) and a pious person (Buzurg). He was a resident of Yemen and passed away in 37 AH. Although he lived during the time of the Prophet (ﷺ), he did not get the opportunity to meet him. Yet, he had immense love for the Prophet (ﷺ). He had an elderly mother and always treated her kindly and served her. The Prophet (ﷺ) knew him.

It is narrated in a Hadith that Umar (R.A.) said, "The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said, 'A man named Uways will come to you from Yemen. He has no one in Yemen except his mother. He suffered from leucoderma (vitiligo). He prayed to Allah, and Allah cured his disease, but a spot the size of a dinar or a dirham remained white on his body. If any of you meet him, let him ask him to seek forgiveness (Istighfar) for you.'" (Sahih Muslim, Hadith 2542)

The incident of the Companions meeting Uways al-Qarani is also narrated in the Hadith. However, nowhere is there any mention of such a tale. It is mentioned in Sahih Muslim that when Umar (R.A.) met Uways al-Qarani, he asked him about all the signs the Prophet (ﷺ) had mentioned to identify him. In this narration, Umar (R.A.), following the Prophet's instructions, asked him to seek forgiveness for him, and Uways al-Qarani prayed for Umar (R.A.). The following year during the Hajj season, a person from the area where Uways al-Qarani lived came, and Umar (R.A.) inquired about him. (See: Sahih Muslim, Hadith 2542)
