An Incorrect Practice

Does the Prayer of a Masbuq Person Become Invalid if He Mistakenly Greets (Says Salam) to Both Sides?

Many people, if they mistakenly say the greetings (Salam) to both sides along with the Imam while in the state of a Masbuq (one who joins the congregation late), believe that their prayer has become invalid. Consequently, they start the entire prayer anew.

This practice is wrong. They probably do this due to a lack of knowledge of the religious ruling (Mas'ala). The rule in this situation is that even if one has said Salam to both sides, if no act that invalidates the prayer has been done, they should stand up and complete the remaining units (rak'ats). At the end, they should perform the Prostration of Forgetfulness (Sajda Sahw).

And it is, of course, known to everyone that a Masbuq person should not say Salam with the Imam. Rather, they should stand up to complete the remaining rak'ats after the Imam has finished giving the Salam to both sides.

May Allah grant us the ability to know the rulings correctly and act upon them. - Abu Ahmad

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, October 2014, www.alkawsar.com

A False Narration

Allah Used to Seek the Blessing of Health (Na'uzubillah)

It is acknowledged in the Qur'an that there was a dialogue between Prophet Moses (Musa A.S.) and Allah. This is why Moses (A.S.) is referred to as Musa Kalimullah (Moses, the one who spoke to Allah). Capitalizing on this, a class of storytellers narrate many strange and baseless incidents in society under the title 'Dialogue Between Moses (A.S.) and Allah,' which may heat up the lecture halls but have no foundation.

One of the famous dialogues among these is about the blessing of health:

Moses (A.S.) asked Allah, "O Allah! If You were Moses and I were Allah, what would You ask for?" Allah said, "That is not My Majesty." Moses insisted, "I know, but if it were so, what would You ask for?" Then Allah is claimed to have said, "I would ask for health."

This fabricated tale is narrated to explain how great a blessing health is, but it has no connection whatsoever with Moses (A.S.).

The implication of such a dialogue is that Moses (A.S.) was mocking Allah (Na'uzubillah - May Allah protect us from such a thought), which is never appropriate for a Prophet. To attribute such a statement to a Prophet is an act of great disrespect and a reprehensible sin, which must be avoided.

One should rather quote the beautiful sayings about the blessing of health that have come down in the authentic Hadith.

The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said:

نِعْمَتَانِ مَغْبُونٌ فِيهِمَا كَثِيرٌ مِنَ النَّاسِ: الصِّحَّةُ وَالْفَرَاغُ

"There are two blessings in which many people are deceived (or suffer loss): Health and Free Time." (Sahih Bukhari, Hadith 6412)

People do not utilize health and free time appropriately. When they fall ill or become busy, they say, "If I were healthy now, or if I had free time, I would have done such-and-such good deed." Or they say, "When I get healthy or get free time, I will do such-and-such good deed." Yet, they wasted their previous time of health or leisure. The Hadith draws attention to this very point.

Therefore, saying baseless things when authentic narrations exist is nothing but ignorance. We must refrain from this, and we should neither speak anything without verification nor spread something immediately upon hearing it.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, November 2014, www.alkawsar.com

An Incorrect Notion

Does the Mouth Remain Impure for Forty Days After Mentioning the Name 'Pig'?

Many people are heard saying that if one pronounces the name Pig, the mouth remains impure (na-paak) for forty days, and that one should say "Khinzeer" (the Arabic word for Pig) instead of Shukor. This statement is completely baseless.

Furthermore, Pig is an English word, and its Arabic equivalent is Khinzeer. What is the meaning behind the idea that pronouncing the name of the same animal in English or Bengali makes the mouth impure, but pronouncing it in Arabic does not? May Allah protect us from uttering baseless things.

A Baseless Story

The Story of Hasan al-Basri Praying on a Prayer Mat Over Water and Rabi'ah al-Basriyyah Praying on a Prayer Mat Over Air

Rabi'ah al-Basriyyah (often referred to as Rabi'ah al-Basri) was a famous devout woman ('Abidah) of the second century AH. Her biography is recorded in various biographical works, including Siyar A'lam al-Nubala' by Imam Dhahabi, Wafayat al-A'yan by Ibn Khallikan, and At-Tabaqat al-Kubra by Sha'rani. However, many fabricated tales and narratives about her are prevalent in society.

One story frequently heard about her and the famous Tabi'i (successor to the Companions) Hasan al-Basri (may Allah have mercy on them both) is as follows:

Once, Hasan al-Basri (R.A.) spread his prayer mat and prayed upon water. When Rabi'ah al-Basriyyah learned of this, she spread her prayer mat and prayed upon air (in the open space). When Hasan al-Basri (R.A.) came to know this, he said, "Rabi'ah's status (Maqam) is far above mine."

This tale is completely baseless. It is an entirely fictional story that has no connection to reality. This incident is not mentioned in any reliable history book or any authentic biographical work written about Rabi'ah al-Basriyyah.

Such stories are concocted merely to illustrate how great saints (Buzurg) they were.

It is an acknowledged fact that they were great figures. They were foremost in asceticism (Zuhd), piety (Taqwa), detachment from the world, and fear of God. But why is there a need to prove their sainthood with such tales? And what connection do these things have with true sainthood anyway?

It is acknowledged that different miraculous occurrences (Karamat) appear from the friends of Allah (Awliya') at various times. At the same time, it is also acknowledged that Karamat has no relation to sainthood. The measure of sainthood and being beloved by Allah is piety (Taqwa)—that is, the fear of Allah and living life according to the Sunnah.

Furthermore, another aspect of this fabricated story is visible: one person prays on a mat over water, and upon hearing this, the other prays on a mat over air—as if a competition of sainthood is going on! The people of Allah seek to conceal themselves. But this story depicts respected saints like them as showcasing their spiritual status. Na'uzubillah (May Allah protect us from such a thought). This is a great slander against them!

Another point is that Hasan al-Basri (R.A.) passed away in 110 AH. Rabi'ah al-Basriyyah was born in 99 or 100 AH. This means that at the time of Hasan al-Basri's death, Rabi'ah al-Basriyyah (R.A.) was at most 10 or 11 years old. In Siyar A'lam al-Nubala' (8/241), Dhahabi (R.A.) states that Rabi'ah al-Basriyyah died in 180 AH and is reputed to have lived for eighty years. This fact alone proves the falsity of the incident.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, December 2014, www.alkawsar.com

Another Incorrect Pronunciation

'Muazzim' or 'Muazzem'

The person who gives the call to prayer (Adhan) is called a Mu'adhdhin. However, some people pronounce this word as 'Muazzim' ending with the letter 'M' (Arabic: Meem). This is an incorrect pronunciation of the word. The correct pronunciation is 'Mu'adhdhin'.

The word Mu'adhdhin comes from the word Adhan. Just as the word Adhan ends with the letter 'N' (Arabic: Noon), so too should the word Mu'adhdhin end with the letter 'N' (Arabic: Noon). Therefore, one should say Mu'adhdhin, not Muazzim.

Source: Monthly Al Kawsar, December 2014, www.alkawsar.com

The Story of Defecation in Noah (Nuh A.S.)'s Ark

Another Baseless Story

The Story of Noah (A.S.)'s Flood and the Old Woman

Just before the Flood of Noah (A.S.), an old woman said to him, "O Noah! Take me with you on your Ark before the Flood." However, Noah (A.S.) forgot the old woman's request at that moment. And, through the power of Allah (Qudrat), the old woman did not even notice the Flood.
